bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mazyck P. Ravenel, October 31, 1925

div1.p: Kean discusses Russell's article on Gorgas and comments on the errors in the Marie Gorgas biography of her husband. Included is an autograph note by Kean.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Mazyck P. Ravenel, October 31, 1925
div1.opener:
See last page of file -
October 31, 1925.
Dr. Mazyck P. Ravenel,
University of Missouri,
Columbia, Missouri
My dear Dr. Ravenel:
div1.p:
I owe you an apology for not having written sooner
to thank you for the Sigma Xi Quarterly and tell you about my
talk with Russell. I sat at the same table with him at the
dinner given to the Foreign Delegates at our Annual Meeting
in New York so that I did not have much of an opportunity to
discuss the matter with him. I told him, however, of receiv-
ing your letter and reading his address in the Quarterly and
said that when he spoke of General Gorgas cleaning up Havana
in 90 days he meant getting rid of most of the mosquitoes,
not a physical cleansing of the city. He said “Of course”
and did not seem to realize at all the ambiguity of his state-
ment to people who are not familiar with the actual conditions.

I have not read “Sanitation in Panama” since it first
came out. I will get hold of a copy and look over it again
to see just what Gorgas says about Havana. I am sure, how-
ever, he does not make any such claims to cleaning the city
as Hendrick and his good wife make in their interesting but
most inaccurate book. By the way, I notice that they say
that he retired from active service (for age) three days after
the Armistice. Whereas, in fact, he retired on his sixty-
fourth birthday in accordance with law five weeks before the
Armistice, to-wit, October 3, 1918. Of course this mis-
statement is of no importance except as an example of the in-
accuracies of the book.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, J. R. KEAN
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retired
Editor. JRK/W
P. S. He was kept on active pay
after his retirement in order to finish his report of his visit
to France, but was no longer Surgeon General. Gen. Ireland was
in charge of that job-
